Rouché's theorem

If α∈C\alpha \in \Cα∈C satisfies 0<∣α∣<10 < \abs{\alpha} < 10<∣α∣<1 and if n∈N={1,2,3,…}n \in \N = \set{1, 2, 3, \ldots}n∈N={1,2,3,…} show that the equation

ez(z−1)n=αe^z\p{z - 1}^n = \alphaez(z−1)n=α

has exactly nnn simple roots int he half-plane {z∣Re⁡z>0}\set{z \mid \Re{z} > 0}{z∣Rez>0}.
Solution.

Consider the homotopy ft(z)=etz(z−1)nf_t\p{z} = e^{tz} \p{z - 1}^nft​(z)=etz(z−1)n. Observe that on the circle ∣z−1∣=1\abs{z - 1} = 1∣z−1∣=1, we have

∣ft(z)∣=etRe⁡z≥e0=1>∣α∣,\abs{f_t\p{z}} = e^{t\Re{z}} \geq e^0 = 1 > \abs{\alpha},∣ft​(z)∣=etRez≥e0=1>∣α∣,

so ft(z)−αf_t\p{z} - \alphaft​(z)−α never vanishes on this circle. Thus, by Cauchy's theorem, if γ\gammaγ is the curve ∣z−1∣=1\abs{z - 1} = 1∣z−1∣=1, we get

12πi∫γft′(z)ft(z)−α=12πi∫ft(γ)dww−α\frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_\gamma \frac{f_t'\p{z}}{f_t\p{z} - \alpha} = \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{f_t\p{\gamma}} \frac{\diff{w}}{w - \alpha}2πi1​∫γ​ft​(z)−αft′​(z)​=2πi1​∫ft​(γ)​w−αdw​

is a constant. When t=0t = 0t=0, we get f0(z)=(z−1)nf_0\p{z} = \p{z - 1}^nf0​(z)=(z−1)n, so the integral is equal to nnn, and by the argument principle, this means that ez(z−1)n=αe^z\p{z - 1}^n = \alphaez(z−1)n=α has precisely nnn solutions in the interior of the circle ∣z−1∣=1\abs{z - 1} = 1∣z−1∣=1.

To show that these solutions are simple, suppose www is a solution to the equation. Then if f(z)=ez(z−1)nf\p{z} = e^z\p{z - 1}^nf(z)=ez(z−1)n, then

f′(z)=ez(z−1)n+nez(z−1)n−1  ⟹  f′(w)=α+nαw−1.f'\p{z} = e^z\p{z - 1}^n + ne^z\p{z - 1}^{n-1} \implies f'\p{w} = \alpha + \frac{n\alpha}{w - 1}.f′(z)=ez(z−1)n+nez(z−1)n−1⟹f′(w)=α+w−1nα​.

This is 000 if and only if

1+nw−1=0  ⟹  w=1−n,1 + \frac{n}{w - 1} = 0 \implies w = 1 - n,1+w−1n​=0⟹w=1−n,

but Re⁡(1−n)≤0\Re\p{1 - n} \leq 0Re(1−n)≤0, but Re⁡w>0\Re{w} > 0Rew>0. Thus, any solution to the equation must be simple.
